results.title: Clean cuisine
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), John Budd and Mike O'Donnell
results.brief_description: An episode of ‘Countrywide’ where reporter Jill Singer examines the use of chemicals in Australian farming and the consequences of the presence of chemical residues in our food products.

results.title: Clean and bright
results.brief_description: The need for cleanliness in both man and animals is illustrated using Mr Williams and his pet elephant, Maxwell. Mr Williams has provided all the necessities of life for Maxwell, except for a bath. Also shows animals and children cleaning themselves in various ways and provides a solution to Maxwell’s problem.

results.title: Claymation: three dimensional clay animation (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Will Vinton Productions, Pyramid Films, Susan Shadburne and Will Vinton
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the principles and processes of three dimensional clay animation. Shows the mixing of colour, creation of characters that move, production and editing of the live action film which serves as an animation guide, music scoring and the slow demanding process of working with the clay itself. Includes scenes from “Closed Monday” and “Martin the Cobbler”.

results.title: Claycraft at Denby
results.brief_description: The Denby Potteries were founded in 1809. This film shot at these Potteries, covers the manufacture from start to finish of English kitchenware (teapots, casserole dishes, etc), ending with a tour of the Potteries’ new showrooms, where the articles displayed show the modern trend of design in everyday ware.

results.title: Clay: or the origin of the species
results.creator_credit: Contemporary Films, McGraw-Hill Films and Eliot Noyes
results.brief_description: An art film in which three-dimensional forms of modelling clay are used to express a visual and amusing variation on a theory of evolution as suggested by the simple lifeforms which emerge from graphic motions of a clay sea. Best Film, 6th Annual Annecy film festival.

results.title: Clay Modelling: The Human Face
results.brief_description: The human face in all its expressiveness is shown modelled from inanimate clay. This is a fascinating program for beginners, and for those with some experience, as it is packed with hints and useful information.
results.description: The human face in all its expressiveness is shown modelled from inanimate clay. This is a fascinating program for beginners, and for those with some experience, as it is packed with hints and useful information.

results.title: Clay in action
results.brief_description: Step-by-step demonstrations of a sculptor modelling a head in clay. Shows how he packs clay on wooden supports; the first rough carving; measuring the model with calipers and cutting the measurements into the clay, carving out the larger primary, carving out minor planes; using the thumbs to blend, model and smooth; finishing.
results.description: Step-by-step demonstrations of a sculptor modelling a head in clay. results.title: Clay in a special way (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Oak Creek Films, Bill Snider and Larry Schultz
results.brief_description: The film examines the positive, creative process of an art project with 4th, 5th and 6th grade students, handicapped and non-handicapped. An honest instructor expresses his initial doubts about teaching a “mainstreamed” class. Deaf and blind students participate with the aid of sign language interpreters and sighted students’ oral descriptions. Students are given information on the historical usage of clay through slides and a trip to a local museum. An artist, Maynard Fishler, visits the classroom to discuss his work. Throughout the project, a multi-sensory approach is used. The students decide to interpret transportation with clay, each student developing his own personal communication. The clay sculptures are the visual, concrete expression of a successful learning experience for all. Communication and creativity on may levels are results no less important.
